node.title: A Broadway Couple Says ‘I Do’ to Great Applause
node.alt: Devario Simmons, left, and Bryan Terrell Clark, were introduced in 2019 by a friend of Mr. Clark. They married on Jan. 1 at the Chandelier Room at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif.
node.description: Bryan Terrell Clark, an actor, and Devario Simmons, a costume designer, had a common bond in challenging upbringings. Their relationship was the opposite.
node.content: ["Before the Omicron surge caused dozens of people to drop off the wedding guest list of Bryan Terrell Clark and Devario D. Simmons, it shut down \u201cThoughts of A Colored Man,\u201d the Broadway show that counted Mr. Clark as a star and Mr. Simmons as costume designer. Mr. Clark hated not having the chance to take a final bow with his castmates. But he did have his final bow as a single man to look forward to.", "\u201cFrom day one, there was never a question in my head that I was supposed to marry this man,\u201d he said.", "Mr. Clark, 41, met Mr. Simmons, 31, on Dec. 10, 2019. Mr. Clark\u2019s best friend, Rodrick Covington, may have been responsible. Earlier that month, Mr. Covington had pointed out that Mr. Clark, who at the time was playing George Washington in the Broadway production of \u201cHamilton,\u201d had become a habitual Tinder-swiper.", "\u201cHe was like, \u2018What are you looking for?\u2019\u201d Mr. Clark said. \u201cHe asked me to describe the man of my dreams.\u201d Then Mr. Covington asked if Mr. Clark had any friends willing to play matchmaker. When Mr. Clark said he did, Mr. Covington advised him to delete his Tinder app right away.", "\u201cRodrick is a powerful manifester,\u201d said Mr. Clark. On Dec. 9, 2019, while Mr. Clark had dinner at Amy Ruth\u2019s in Harlem with the actor Stephen Conrad Moore, Mr. Covington\u2019s manifestation began to take shape.", "\u201cStephen said he knew a great costume designer,\u201d said Mr. Clark, who then asked to see a picture and was shown one of Mr. Simmons. He had the physical qualities of Mr. Clark\u2019s dream man: Mr. Simmons looked fit, \u201clike someone who takes care of his temple,\u201d said Mr. Clark, who recalled telling Mr. Moore that, in terms of character, \u201cI was looking for someone who was spiritual and a good communicator.\u201d", "That night, Mr. Moore introduced the two men on Instagram, writing, as Mr. Simmons recalled, \u201c\u2018Hey gentlemen, I think you\u2019re both great people and you two should connect.\u2019\u201d In reply, Mr. Simmons said, \u201cThank you. I\u2019m sure we\u2019ll kick you off soon so we can connect privately.\u201d", "The following night, they met at Hell\u2019s Kitchen, a restaurant in that neighborhood of Manhattan. Mr. Simmons, who at the time was working on costumes for the Off Broadway show \u201cTumacho,\u201d lived nearby. Mr. Clark, who lived in Los Angeles, was staying on the Upper West Side temporarily for \u201cHamilton.\u201d A sense of connection quickly came over them.", "\u201cIt wasn\u2019t necessarily the kind of thing where, as soon as you see the person there\u2019s fireworks,\u201d Mr. Clark said. \u201cIt was more like I felt like I knew him already. It was so easy.\u201d", "Both men had experienced formative relationships that were anything but easy. Mr. Clark grew up in Baltimore with a younger brother and sister. He was nearing adolescence when he started to understand that his father, George Clark, a factory worker, had a drug problem. \u201cHe was this tumultuous energy in and out of our lives,\u201d Mr. Clark said.", "His parents divorced in 2002, the same year that George Clark, who still lives in Baltimore, got clean. Father and son reunited soon after. Now, \u201cmy father is one of my best friends,\u201d said Mr. Clark, who also counts his mother, Tanya Young, a retired elementary school principal and pastor who lives in Decatur, Ill., among his closest confidantes. But coming out to her in his early 20s was hard.", "\u201cMy father told me what every son wants to hear, which is, \u2018I love you unconditionally,\u2019\u201d he said. But when Mr. Clark first discussed his sexuality with his mother, a former Sunday school teacher at a nondenominational church, after he graduated from Temple University in 2003, \u201cshe said, \u2018I\u2019m wrestling with my belief system,\u2019\u201d he recalled. She was still wrestling when he enrolled in Yale School of Drama, where he earned a master\u2019s degree in acting in 2006, and continued to well after Mr. Clark\u2019s Broadway career kicked off when he was cast as Marvin Gaye in \u201cMotown the Musical\u201d in 2013.", "\u201cMy mom didn\u2019t come around to full acceptance until we were married,\u201d he said.", "Mr. Simmons\u2019s youth in Greenville, S.C., was marked by the death of his father, Raymond Simmons, in a motorcycle accident when he was 7. \u201cIt changed my life in ways I couldn\u2019t imagine,\u201d he said. \u201cI had to grow up instantly.\u201d", "He and his younger sister and brother were raised by his mother, Kimeco Williams, who owns a local hair salon, and grandmother, Helena C. Williams. Being the oldest left him in a position of authority he often felt unready for. \u201cI had to make a lot of choices I wouldn\u2019t have had to make if my father had been there,\u201d he said.", "The choice to come out at 21 \u2014 just before he graduated from Clemson University in 2013 \u2014 was as fraught for Mr. Simmons as it was for Mr. Clark. \u201cBeing from that region of the country, I was always taught that being gay was wrong and bad,\u201d said Mr. Simmons, who earned a master\u2019s degree in costume design from Virginia Commonwealth University in 2016. But Helena Williams, who still speaks to her grandson three times a day from her home in Greenville, \u201cwas instrumental in me saying my piece,\u201d he said.", "Mr. Simmons and Mr. Clark both understood the value of honest conversation well before they met. But each had experienced trouble getting there, not just with their parents, but also with previous partners. So when they arrived at the restaurant for their first date, their intentions, separately set, were in alignment.", "\u201cA lot of people try to hide things on first dates,\u201d Mr. Simmons said. \u201cI showed up with the attitude of, nothing is taboo.\u201d For example, \u201cI was fine talking about how I would like to have kids in the future.\u201d Mr. Clark was fine with that, too.", "He was less fine with the idea of saying goodbye to Mr. Simmons when his six-week run in \u201cHamilton\u201d finished in February 2020, and he was due in Vancouver to shoot a role in the television show \u201cSnowpiercer.\u201d The couple had become as inseparable as Mr. Clark\u2019s acting schedule allowed, and \u201cSnowpiercer,\u201d along with a subsequent speaking tour Mr. Clark had already booked, meant spending weeks apart.", "Before long, though, they were back together. In March 2020, as the pandemic gripped the country, Mr. Clark, who by then had returned to his home in Los Angeles, invited Mr. Simmons to quarantine with him. \u201cIt could have been a nightmare,\u201d Mr. Clark said. \u201cI was inviting someone I had only been dating a few months to come stay with me for what we thought would be weeks.\u201d Instead, they were holed up together at Mr. Clark\u2019s house for five months.", "One morning in the summer of 2020, Mr. Clark woke up without Mr. Simmons by his side. He found him in the kitchen. \u201cDevario had never really cooked in New York, but there he was, making breakfast,\u201d he said. \u201cHe\u2019s from South Carolina \u2014 he was making crab cakes and grits. That\u2019s the day I started looking for rings.\u201d", "By Dec. 31, 2020, Mr. Clark and Mr. Simmons had both gone back to work. Mr. Clark was in Canada, this time to film a role in the Disney+ movie \u201cSneakerella.\u201d Mr. Simmons was in Greenville, teaching remotely at Ithaca College, where he was an assistant professor in the theater department. To celebrate New Year\u2019s Eve, Mr. Clark had arranged party on a boat for a dozen friends in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, where he and Mr. Simmons would reunite.", "At the stroke of midnight, both had their sea legs and glasses of Champagne. Before Mr. Simmons had a chance to sip from his, Mr. Clark dropped to one knee and proposed. Mr. Simmons gasped, and gave a stunned, ecstatic \u201cyes.\u201d", "Their Jan. 1 wedding was held at the Chandelier Room at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif. The celebration actually started on Dec. 31, 2021, to mirror their engagement. At 10:30 p.m., their 148 vaccinated guests (down from 175 because of the Omicron surge) began mingling over cocktails and hors d\u2019oeuvres. When it was time to start the countdown to the New Year, they paused as two officiants, the married Broadway actors John Eric Parker and Charles West, both ordained by the Universal Life Church for the occasion, asked guests to extend their hands and say a prayer for the husbands-to-be.", "Mr. Simmons and Mr. Clark, in matching tuxedos that Mr. Simmons helped design, stood on a landing holding hands to receive that prayer, before Mr. Parker, as lead officiant, delivered them to the night\u2019s denouement. The New Year began as a choir filed in, singing Kirk Franklin\u2019s \u201cWanna Be Happy?\u201d The grooms exchanged rings and were pronounced married, the crowd whooping in appreciation as they embraced and kissed.", "When Jan. 1, 2022", "Where The Chandelier Room at Santa Anita Park, Arcadia, Calif.", "VIPs Mr. Clark and Mr. Simmons were the stars of the night, but not the only ones in the room. In attendance were several actors, including Angela Bassett, Aisha Hinds, Courtney Vance, John Clarence Stewart and Yvonne Orji (\u201cMy bestie,\u201d Mr. Clark said).", "Crabs Times Two Instead of a sit-down dinner, guests nibbled throughout the evening. Each groom chose a menu passed from two separate serving stations. Mr. Clark\u2019s included Maryland crab cakes and Parmesan grits. Mr. Simmons\u2019s had lobster mac-and-cheese and chicken and waffles.", "Homeward Bound Mr. Clark and Mr. Simmons did not return to Los Angeles after their honeymoon in Colombia, but to Manhattan, where they started renting an apartment in Hell\u2019s Kitchen in 2021. Both are hoping for a return to normalcy on Broadway, though they will always lament the premature closing of \u201cThoughts of a Colored Man,\u201d the first show written and directed by Black men with Black men in the lead roles. \u201cSaying goodbye to something so groundbreaking was heartbreaking,\u201d Mr. Clark said."]
